XWH v XWI

XWH v XWI
[2025] SGFC 138

Case Number:SSP 316/2024
Decision Date:16 December 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Mark Cheng (PKWA Law Practice LLC) for the applicant; the respondent in-person and unrepresented.
Parties: XWH — XWI

Family Law – Personal Protection Order

Family Law – Domestic Exclusion Order

16 December 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       This was a dispute between Mother and Son. The Mother was represented by Mr Mark Cheng. The Son was self-represented.

2       I heard the trial and reserved judgment. My decision was delivered on 10 October 2025. These are the reasons for my decision.

3       The essence of this dispute was that the Mother could no longer tolerate living together with her Son given his living habits and bad temper. She thus brought the present application in SSP 316 of 2025 (“SSP 316”). She sought a Personal Protection Order (“PPO”), as well as a Domestic Exclusion Order (“DEO”) against the Son.

4       It was plain to me that the real objective of the Mother’s application in SSP 316 was to obtain the DEO so as to exclude the Son entirely from the flat. The architecture of the provisions relating to family violence in the Women’s Charter make it clear that the court only has the power to grant a DEO in the event a PPO has been granted: s 60B(1) of the Women’s Charter 1961.

5       I found that a PPO should be granted in the present case. For one, it was, in my judgment, likely that the Son would commit family violence on the Mother. Specifically, I found that he would, in all likelihood, lash out at the Mother if she were to do things in the house that were not to his liking. Indeed, on the Son’s own evidence, he would get angry when the Mother would not shut the windows when second-hand cigarette smoke wafted over from the neighbouring unit. He also said his temper flared up when his Mother had forgotten to close a bottle of expensive vitamins he had bought for her on a few occasions.

6       Anger alone, in the ordinary course of things, would be insufficient to establish the likelihood of family violence. It is human, all too human, to feel anger when our boundaries have been crossed. The evidence in the present case, however, does show that the Son would act on his anger.

7       First, it was quite clear that the Son would go to extreme lengths to minimise or avoid the risks posed by second-hand smoke. This was evident, not only from the work he had done around the house to keep out second-hand smoke, the complaint he had filed to National Environment Agency about the neighbours smoking, but also in his testimony where he described how he would continually try to explain to the Mother, the perils of second and third hand smoke.

8       Second, the evidence also showed that the Son had indeed lashed out at the Mother. The Mother had, in her affidavit, recounted an incident on 19th October 2024. She had left the window open. The Son was enraged. He entered her room, grabbed her arm and pulled her into the kitchen, claiming that she was letting in cigarette smoke and that in so doing, she would increase the risk of cancer.

9       When confronted by Mr Cheng in cross-examination, about whether he had grabbed the Mother’s arm and brought her to the kitchen, the Son’s response is telling: he first claimed he was “not sure” if he had grabbed her arm, then said he definitely held her hand, before attempting to clarify with Mr Cheng what he had meant by his question. The Son, however, did admit that he was angry and that he had asked the Mother to “come and smell this”. Given the Son’s testimony, I accept the Mother’s account of what had happened in this incident on 19th October 2024.

10     In addition to this incident, the Son had also admitted that he would, in a fit of anger, “vent out”.[note: 1] He explained that he would shout as an “outward expression” because he had the “habit of doing that to [his] family members” since he was growing up.[note: 2]

11     It was thus clear to me that the Son was likely to inflict family violence on the Mother, namely, that he would likely either verbally abuse or physically confront her in the event that she had done something in the house that was not to his liking.

12     Having found that the Son was likely to inflict family violence on the Mother, I also found it necessary to order a PPO for the Mother’s personal safety or protection.

13     It is well-established that in assessing the necessity of ordering a PPO, the court assesses the risk of future family violence being committed on the person sought to be protected under the order. There was, in my judgment, a heightened risk of this happening – that is because both the Mother and the Son still continue to live together in the same flat. While the both of them had given evidence of their intention and efforts to find separate housing arrangements, the reality was that none of their plans had been firmed up and cast in stone. Their present living arrangement will thus go on, and with it, only create further opportunities for conflict.

14     Having concluded that a PPO should be granted, I turn now to consider the necessity of ordering a DEO. Given that a DEO may only be ordered in the event a PPO is granted, this implies that the purpose of a DEO is to deal with situations where a PPO alone does not go far enough to ensure the protection or personal safety of the person protected under the order.

15     In this vein, there was the question of whether a DEO was necessary given that the Mother was the legal owner of the flat, and would therefore be able to exclude the Son from the flat by simply exercising her property rights.[note: 3] Mr Cheng alluded to the fact that the Mother had neither the presence or the authority to persuade the Son to move out, and that she had already tried, and failed. Mr Cheng also highlighted that sending the Son an eviction notice might be an exercise in futility as the Son would be resistant to moving out.[note: 4]

16     This question of whether a DEO should be ordered in cases where the person sought to be protected by the DEO is able to, qua legal owner, effectively achieve the same outcome was not a point that I had to decide in the present case. That is because I did not find that the Mother had demonstrated the necessity of a DEO. The Mother stated, in her own affidavit, that her Son’s actions had somewhat toned down with the issuance of an Expedited Order (“EO”) (which is, for all intents and purposes, a temporary PPO issued until the application can be heard by the court – see s 61 of the Women’s Charter 1961). It thus appears that a PPO would be sufficient to ensure her personal safety and protection.

17     I would also add that the evidence before me only went so far as to show that there were clashes between her and the Son over their daily living arrangements in the flat. It did not demonstrate that the Mother was in danger of real bodily harm should the Son continue to live in the flat with her.

18     To sum up, I allowed the Mother’s application for a PPO. In addition to that, I also ordered both the Mother and the Son to attend counselling. The Mother’s application for a DEO was dismissed.

19     Finally, I made no order as to costs given that the Mother did not obtain all the orders that she sought in SSP 316.

[note: 2]Transcript, 19 September 2025 at p 21.

[note: 3]Transcript, 19 September 2025, p 29.

[note: 4]Transcript, 19 September 2025, p 31.

html:
XWG v XWF

XWG v XWF
[2025] SGFC 137

Case Number:SS 2266 and 2272 of 2024
Decision Date:16 December 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The Father in person and unrepresented; The Mother in person and unrepresented.
Parties: XWG — XWF

Family Law – Personal Protection Order

16 December 2025

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       There were two applications before me:

(a)     SS 2266/2024 was the Father’s application against the Mother. He sought a PPO to protect both himself and the two sons (“A” and “B”) against the Mother.

(b)     SS 2272/2024 was the Mother’s application against the Father. She too sought a PPO to protect herself and the two sons against the Father.

2       Judgment was delivered on 20 August 2025. These are the reasons for my decision.

3       Both applications were filed prior to the 2nd of January 2025. There can therefore be no quarrel that the provisions of the Women’s Charter 1961 relating to family violence which were in force prior to that date apply to the present applications.

4       To succeed in their respective applications for a PPO, the Father and the Mother had to establish the following two requirements on a balance of probabilities:

(a)     First, that the respondent had either committed family violence, or was likely to commit family violence.

(b)     Second, that it was necessary for the court to grant the PPO for the protection of the persons for whom the order was sought.

5       It also goes without saying, and this is well-established in our case law, that the point of such orders is to protect, and not to punish respondents for any acts of family violence that they may have committed: XQW v XQV and other matters [2025] SGFC 91 at [1] citing WSD v WSE [2024] SGFC 1; XEP v XEQ [2024] SGFC 95 at [19(b)(i)].

6       Both the Father and the Mother mainly rely on an incident that had taken place on 19 November 2024 to support their respective applications. The both of them, however, presented slightly accounts of what had transpired that day.

7       This was the Father’s account. He said that he had caught the Mother red-handed having an affair with her ex-boyfriend. He confronted the Mother. He threatened to divorce her. This provoked the Mother. She became agitated. As a result, the quarrel escalated. The Mother had, allegedly, taken B, and tried to throw him off the balcony. The Father stepped in to restrain her. The Father gained control of B. It was then that the Mother tried to attack A. The Father called in his father-in-law and had a word with him about the Mother’s psychiatric issues. According to the Father, he thought that the reason the Wife was acting up was due to her mental condition. The police were eventually called in, but no action was taken as it was a family issue.

8       The Mother, on the other hand, did not deny meeting her ex-boyfriend on that day. What she did deny, was that she was having an affair with him, or that she slept with him on that day. She said they talked. After they finished their conversation, her ex-boyfriend drove her home. When she returned home, she got into an argument with the Father who was badgering her for the baby bonus money. During their discussion, the Father discovered that the Mother had met up with her ex-boyfriend. He was enraged. The argument escalated. The Father alleged that the Mother had gone to a hotel with her ex-boyfriend. He began to beat her. The Mother alleges that it was the Father who had threatened to throw their son from the balcony, and not her.

9       Based on the evidence put before me, the most that can be said was that there was a quarrel between the Father and the Mother. In this regard, I find the Mother’s recounting of events, specifically, that the reason for their heated quarrel was because the Father had discovered that the Mother had met up with her ex-boyfriend, to be more plausible as opposed to the Father’s account. That was because the Father did not strike me as a man who would let such a thing slide. Insofar as both the Father and the Mother accused each other of trying to throw B off the balcony, there was nothing to support or corroborate their respective accounts. The most that can be said, therefore, is that both their sons were likely caught up amidst their domestic quarrel, and unfortunately, had to witness both their parents fighting. This, however, did not mean that family violence had been inflicted on both sons by either parent.

10     Apart from this incident, the Father also raised the issue of the Mother’s psychiatric condition. To support his assertion that the Mother had a psychiatric condition, he pointed me to a referral letter from Hospital R. That letter states that the Mother had been admitted for “new onset psychosis” and that she was following up with Hospital R’s psychiatric department. The letter, however, does not state the severity of the Mother’s condition, nor does it detail how her condition would affect those around her, namely, the Father as well as their two sons.

11     In short, the evidence before me does not go so far as to establish that the Mother’s alleged psychiatric condition was so severe such that it could be concluded that she was likely to commit family violence on either her two sons, or the Father.

12     Finally, the last major point which the Father had raised was in relation to an incident where the Mother had allegedly pushed A down the stairs. The Father had attached a report from A’s playschool. That report states that A had been observed limping. The teacher asked A what had happened. A said that the Mother had pushed him down the stairs. The teacher was taken aback. She shared it with the school principal. The Mother stated that A was fine and did not have any fall at home.

13     In addition to the report, a series of screenshots were also produced. Those screenshots contained text messages which corroborated the report from the school. These screenshots were sent in a group chat which included both the Father, the Mother and the school teachers.

14     I note that the Mother had indeed texted the group chat to state that A was fine and did not have any fall at home. This was, however, quite different from what she had stated in her testimony. She recounted, when asked why A would accuse her of pushing him down the stairs, that A had tripped over a small bicycle. She was adamant that she remembered this incident. But if this was indeed the case, and the Mother knew that A was limping because he had tripped over a bicycle, why did she not simply communicate this on the group chat? Instead – she said, on the group chat, that A was fine and that he did not have any fall at home.

15     While this discrepancy between the Mother’s testimony and what the contemporaneous evidence shows, may suggest that the Mother was, in some way, responsible for A’s limp, the Father’s account is based entirely on what the teachers had told him, which was in turn, entirely based on what A had told them. In other words, the Father’s case that A had indeed been pushed by the Mother is based on hearsay: see XOD v XOC and other matters [2025] SGFC 73 at [72]; XJZ v XJY and another matter [2025] SGFC 30 at [32]. The teachers had not been called as witnesses, and there was therefore no opportunity for the Wife to quiz them on what had actually happened that day and what A had told them. Given this, I did not find that the Father had indeed made out his case that the Mother had pushed A down a flight of stairs.

16     For completeness, I would also state that I do not find that either the Mother, or the Father, were likely to commit family violence on their children. The evidence showed that while their relationship was a dysfunctional one, their children were not the main targets of their fury, but rather, unfortunate bystanders to their quarrels and fights. For instance, the Mother herself told me that the Father would not hit the children – rather, she had taken out a PPO for her children because she did not want them to keep seeing her being beaten up by the Father.

17     In this connection, I also found that it was not necessary to order a PPO for the protection of the children. As I have mentioned, the evidence did not show that either the Father, or the Mother, posed a threat to the children.

18     Rather, I found that both the Father and the Mother did, in their own way, care for their sons. For instance, the Mother had shared, in her testimony, the sort of life she envisioned for the both of them, and how she wanted to raise them. The Father had also shared how he would do anything to ensure that both his sons were safe – and that included taking matters into his own hands. In addition, the Father’s witness, who was his sister-in-law,[note: 1] also gave evidence that the Father had been good towards his children, and that he loved them – I saw no evidence or reason to doubt her testimony.

19     In short, I did not find that a PPO should be ordered for both children against either parent.

20     That being said, I found that a PPO should be ordered for the Mother, against the Father. I found it likely that the Father would commit family violence on the Mother – as I have explained, the Father had told me that he was willing to take matters into his own hands if he thought that his children were in danger. The Mother is currently having custody of the children. I therefore considered it likely that the Father would go to confront the Mother if he thought that his sons were in danger.

21     I would also add that notwithstanding the fact that the Father was currently in prison pursuant to a detention order for secret society activity,[note: 2] that in no way diminished the necessity of a PPO. In fact, this increased the need for the PPO. For one, while the Father was incarcerated, he had not been able to see the children. It was clear to me that this only served to amplify his existing concerns over their safety which were borne out of the strained relations which he had with the Mother. This, coupled with what the Father had told me, that he was willing to take matters into his own hands, made it clear that a PPO was indeed necessary for the Mother’s personal protection so as to avoid a situation where the Father would make trouble for her upon his release.

22     As for the Father’s application for a PPO for himself, I did not see a basis to grant such an order. For one, and in the Father’s own words – he had brought the application mainly because he was concerned for the children’s safety and he did not really see a need for a PPO for himself. In that vein, the incidents that he complained of mainly centered on what he says were acts of family violence that the Mother had committed on the children – I thought it clear from the testimony that I had heard, as well as the evidence put before me, that the Mother had not committed family violence on the Father. In any event, I also did not find it likely that the Mother would commit family violence on him – I gathered from her testimony that she wished to give the Father a wide berth, given the state of her relationship with him. That much was also evident from the access arrangements to the children which are being facilitated by a third party, thereby removing the need for the Mother to come into contact with the Father. In this vein, and for the same reasons, I also did not find it necessary to order a PPO for the Father’s protection.

23     To sum up, I granted the Mother a PPO for herself against the Father. In addition to this, I also ordered that the both of them attend counselling.

[note: 1]Transcript, Day 1 at p 57.

[note: 2]Transcript, Day 1 at p 12, lns 17 – 18.

html:
XVZ v XWA

XVZ v XWA
[2025] SGFC 133

Case Number:SS 1722/2024
Decision Date:11 December 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Chua Wei Yuan
Counsel Name(s): The complainant in person; Mathea Lim, Sabrina Chau (PKWA Law Practice LLC) for the respondent.
Parties: XVZ — XWA

Family Violence

11 December 2025

Judgment reserved.

District Judge Chua Wei Yuan:

1       This is a summons for a personal protection order (“PPO”) and domestic exclusion order (“DEO”) which engages a slightly unusual issue of whether family violence is committed where a respondent does not directly inflict physical violence but whose conduct allegedly affects the tendency of the putative victim to engage in self-injurious behaviour (“SIB”).

Facts

2       The Applicant (“A”) and the Respondent (“R”) are the father and mother, respectively, of their special needs child, a son (“S”) who turns 16 this year. It is common ground that S is high-functioning, intelligent and sensitive. He can be calm and cooperative, but he suffers from autism and when in a state of agitation or distress may exhibit self-injurious behaviour (“SIB”), such as slapping/hitting himself on the head. One of the specialists consulted prescribed a helmet to be worn on S’s head, to prevent or minimise head injury during episodes of SIB.

3       A’s case essentially is that R has been conducting herself to deliberately elicit SIB from S, by ignoring S’s expressed boundaries and using his neurological vulnerabilities as tools of manipulation. In this regard, A presents 6 complaints:

No

Date

Event

1.

7 Sep 2024

R confined S to his bedroom, and caused/allowed S to engage in SIB, which led to foot injuries.

2.

Regular occurrence since March 2023; latest incident on 6 Sep 2024

R would deliberately cause S to hit himself by appearing in front of him despite knowing that S does not want to be in R’s presence.

3.

Regular occurrence; latest incident on 5–6 Sep 2024

R would deliberately make S wear a protective helmet (meant to protect S from head injury due to his SIB) for long periods, which results eventually in ear infections.

4.

Latest incident on 2 Sep 2024

R would deliberately bring S to noisy, enclosed spaces, which causes S to experience sensory overload and exhibiting SIB.

5.

Jul 2024

R would feed S cetirizine without medical need, despite its harms.

6.

Mar 2023

R would feed S melatonin without medical need, despite its harms.



4       R denies all the allegations of FV.

Decision

5       I dismiss the summons as I am not satisfied that FV has been disclosed. My reasons follow.

Legal principles

6       To obtain a PPO, A must show that R has, on a balance of probabilities, committed FV against the person to be protected, and the PPO is necessary for that person’s protection or personal safety. This is provided for under s 65(1) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed) (“WC”):

Protection order

65.—(1)    The court may, upon satisfaction on a balance of probabilities that family violence has been committed or is likely to be committed against a family member and that it is necessary for the protection of the family member, make a protection order restraining the person against whom the order is made from using family violence against the family member.

7       FV is defined in s 64 of the Women’s Charter, as follows:

“family violence” means the commission of any of the following acts:

(a)    wilfully or knowingly placing, or attempting to place, a family member in fear of hurt;

(b)    causing hurt to a family member by such act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt;

(c)    wrongfully confining or restraining a family member against his or her will;

(d)    causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to a family member,

but does not include any force lawfully used in self-defence, or by way of correction towards a child below 21 years of age;

8       To be clear, I proceeded on the basis of the family violence regime before the amendments came into force on 2 January 2025, given that the conduct concerned took place prior to the amendments coming into force, that the complaint was filed prior to the amendments coming into force, and that neither party has asserted that the post-amendment FV regime applies to this case. In any event, I do not consider that it will turn the result of the case.

Whether R committed FV on S

9       In analysing whether R committed FV on S, I have somewhat rearranged the order in which I will address the issues raised:

(a)     Confining S to his bedroom (Part of Incident 1)

(b)     SIB, in particular, being caused by:

(i)       Confining S to his bedroom (Part of Incident 1)

(ii)       Bringing S to noisy, enclosed spaces (Incident 4)

(iii)       Appearing in front of S (Incident 2)

(c)     Making S wear a protective helmet for prolonged periods (Incident 3)

(d)     Feeding cetirizine and melatonin (Incidents 5–6)

Confining S to his bedroom

10     The first complaint is that R confined S to the bedroom on 7 September 2024. According to A, at about 9.00am, R instructed S to enter her bedroom and subsequently closed the door. Thereafter, in the domestic helper’s testimony, screaming and sounds of distress could be heard emanating from the room. S remained in the room with S until about 2.00pm, at which point he exited, exhibiting fresh, visible injuries—a bruised face, and a swollen foot and a limp. According to R, S had stubbed his foot on the wheel of a chair while moving around the room in his agitated state. R says that, as S began engaging in self-injurious behaviour by hitting his own face, R handed S his protective helmet to prevent further injury, and kept S in her bedroom.

11     In my view, the allegation of confinement is not established on a balance of probabilities.

12     A points out that R’s evidence was inconsistent, as R, on the stand, testified that R entered S’s bedroom. However, this in my view does not turn the case. The crucial point is that there was no direct evidence that R had confined S in any room, ie, that R had prevented S from leaving against S’s will.

13     A argues that R, when S was in a state of agitation, had decided to handle the situation alone and not involve the domestic helper, and had “isolated” S behind a closed door. However, I do not consider that the cross-examination allows the situation to be fairly characterised as one of “isolation”. In my view, there is no requirement that R enlist the assistance of someone else when S is in a state of agitation, or that R refrain from “isolating” S. These, in my view, are parenting decisions that are improper for the court to interfere with. A also points out that R failed to call as an independent witness the individual whom R says she was having a phone conversation with. While R’s account of events are uncorroborated, A is in no better a position: to begin with, A was not at the scene, and what he relies on is essentially the testimony of his domestic helper, which itself is circumstantial evidence in some ways. Ultimately, A must prove his contentions on the strength of his own case, not on the weakness of R’s case.

Self-injurious behaviour

14     I next address the major contention in A’s case—that R acted so as to cause S to engage in self-injurious behaviour. This, A says, amounts to FV. This contention deserves closer examination.

15     In my view, it cannot be reasonably argued that conduct which impacts the family member’s self-injurious tendency amounts to wrongful confinement or restraint (ie, para (c) of the definition). I also do not think it normally amounts to wilfully or knowingly placing (or attempting to place) the family member in fear of hurt (ie, para (a) of the definition). This is because the family member is the individual who inflicts the hurt on himself or herself. It would seem somewhat contradictory to claim that the family member at the same time inflicts the hurt on himself/herself, and fears that very hurt.

16     In principle, it seems possible that such conduct satisfies para (d) of the definition, ie, causing continual harassment with intent to cause or knowing that it is likely to cause anguish to the alleged victim. However, two caveats are in order: first, the conduct must amount to continual harassment; and second, it must be established that the respondent either intended to cause or knew that such continual harassment was likely to cause anguish.

17     It might also be that such conduct satisfies para (b) of the definition, ie, causing hurt by an act which is known or ought to have been known would result in hurt. However, it is in my view too simplistic to say that FV is committed (or, at least, a PPO should be granted), as long as the respondent knows or ought to know that his conduct would ultimately result in hurt being inflicted on the alleged victim via SIB.

18     The riposte to the logic that the conduct satisfies para (b) of the definition (and perhaps even para (d)) is that such hurt amounts to a novus actus interveniens—an intervening act by a third party, in this case the alleged victim himself/herself. Otherwise, the legal burden on the respondent would be unbearably onerous. Take, for example, a case where S starts to injure himself. R, instead of restraining S, shouts “Stop it!” at S, hoping or wishing that would stop his SIB, but knowing that S might very well become agitated and continue/escalate his SIB. If that SIB continues or escalates, this logic would mean that the respondent might be taken have committed FV, simply because she knew that S was likely to engage in SIB. But, it also ought not be the case that as a universal rule a respondent can never be held liable just because the act of hurt is consummated by the alleged victim hurting himself/herself. In my view, to obtain a PPO on the basis of para (b) of the definition, the balance is struck by requiring the complainant to establish something more concrete—specifically:

(a)     that there was some loss of control on the part of the alleged victim (in which case it might be said that the SIB was not an intervening act for which the respondent ought not to be held responsible); and

(b)     that the respondent was acting in a way that was calculated to elicit the SIB (in which case it does not lie in the respondent’s mouth to deny that he/she ought to know that the conduct would result in hurt, or at least that that the protection is not necessary).

19     In my view, these two requirements are necessary to establish FV and the necessity for a PPO. If the requirement as to R’s mental state were any lower, it would mean that the victim’s family members become constrained in the way they attempt to manage the SIB, for fear of the spectre of a PPO looming over them. That, in my view, cannot be correct. Ultimately, a finding of FV can eventually sound in criminal sanctions, and the issuance of a PPO must be based on acts of sufficient gravity.

20     I turn to the facts of the case at hand.

21     The central failing in A’s case, in my judgment, is the fact that A has not established that R was acting in a way to elicit the SIB (or, for that matter, that R acted knowing that in all likelihood (ie, not merely that it is likely) that SIB would occur). Ultimately, A’s contentions about R’s character and proclivities were, on the evidence, largely bare assertions. Considering that these accusations are grave, because in substance they accuse R of conducting herself with a view to causing her own son to exhibit SIB, I do not consider them to be proven.

22     Next, insofar as A alleges that there were “regular occurrences”, I do not consider that there are sufficient particulars for R to respond to it. In the event, I proceed only on incidents which A alleged happened on specific dates. I turn to the specific allegations for which a specific date was provided.

(1)   Appearing in front of S

23     A says that S began to exhibit distress since March 2023, when R vetoed S’s wishes to pursue his academic and research interests in France. Despite this, R continued to position herself in S’s immediate presence, knowingly exacerbating his condition (rather than removing herself to alleviate S’s distress). The most recent instance of this was at a staycation on 6 September 2024.

24     In my view, R cannot have committed FV by placing herself in S’s immediate presence, even if this is indeed a trigger for S’s SIB. To hold otherwise is tantamount to saying that the law requires R to alienate herself from her own son at her son’s wishes. That, in my view, cannot be correct.

25     To the extent that A says that R had deliberately timed her appearance to inflict maximum distress and to trigger S’s SIB, A has not sufficiently explained this point.

(2)   Confining S to his bedroom

26     As I explained above, I do not find that R confined S to any bedroom against S’s will on 7 September 2024. Accordingly, the further allegation that such confinement led to S engaging in SIB must fail.

(3)   Bringing S to noisy, enclosed spaces

27     A’s case is that R had brought S to restaurants with loud background sounds to deliberately frustrate S and overwhelm S with external stimuli. However, there is no evidence that R’s conduct was calculated to elicit SIB from S, apart from S’s say-so. This is especially given R’s clarification that:

(a)     S is habituated to using noise-cancelling headphones in such situations; and

(b)     R has developed a routine to help S cope with such situations (where, according to her, the primary source of frustration is the wait for the food rather than the noise).

28     There is no specific evidence, for example, that R had rejected quieter locations in favour of louder locations for no reason other than her own whim and fancy.

29     A argues that R was professionally advised to minimise sensory overload, and she had therefore intentionally subjected S to avoidable distress and self-injury by choosing noisy environments. However, as A notes, R has explained that although S experiences occasional distress, the episodes were short, and easily managed with the helper’s assistance, and calming strategies. Also, R’s position is that regular outings were beneficial for S’s social adaptation. It appears to me that this is simply a clash in parenting styles. In some sense, the analogy to be drawn here is to the management of a mild allergy—in one parent’s opinion, the correct management involves abstinence to avoid an allergic reaction, while in the other parent’s opinion, the correct management involves exposure to build tolerance. I do not think that the fact of professional advice invalidates my analysis. It could very well be—in fact, it appears to be the case—that R sincerely thinks that her management is no less inferior a method than what was professionally advised. It may turn out to be the ill-advised course of action, but, in my view, just because some hurt results from R not observing professional advice does not in and of itself turn the situation into one of FV. In my view, A has far from established in cross-examination that R did not sincerely believe in the logic and efficacy of the way she manages S’s SIB and sensory overloads.

Making S wear a protective helmet for prolonged periods

30     According to A, a therapist hired by R had prescribed a protective helmet for S to wear, to protect himself from the impact of his SIB. He had later specified that the helmet ought to be removed every hour to prevent discomfort. However, R, A says, ignored the guidelines, and instead forced S to wear the helmet for prolonged periods, resulting in an ear infection.

31     In my judgment, the evidence fails to disclose FV.

32     There is insufficient evidence to show on the balance of probabilities that R forced S to don the helmet or to continue wearing it against his will (ie, when he did not want to put it on or when he wanted to take it off). R’s testimony, which was broadly unchallenged, was that S was capable of wearing and taking the helmet off by himself. Given that the helmet both serves a protective function and has a side effect, it seems to me that the proportion of time which S spends with the helmet on or off can be the subject of reasonable disagreement. In fact, the therapist had revised his own recommendation at some point in time. In this regard, even if R did not give express instructions for S to take off the helmet periodically, S could have taken it off if he was uncomfortable. I therefore conclude that R cannot be held to have committed FV against S.

Feeding S cetirizine

33     A claims that it would be harmful to S to feed him cetirizine.

34     However, there is no reliable medical evidence for A’s contention. Specifically, there was no letter (or, for that matter, testimony) from any of S’s attending physicians that cetirizine was to be avoided, despite A’s claims that S’s neurologist had cautioned against it.

35     In cross-examination, A also conceded that cetirizine and melatonin do not cause direct harm, but instead that it can be—in other words, it runs the risk of—exacerbating any seizures that may happen. A also accepted, at least, that cetirizine may on balance be administered in the case of a serious cold. This must mean that cetirizine has the effect of treating symptoms of cold. The point to be gleaned is that cetirizine is not, as A attempts to persuade upon me, all evil and no good. Instead, cetirizine, like several medications, has its intended therapeutic effects and carries side effects, in this case an increased conditional risk of an adverse event. Its administration can be seen as a risk-reward trade-off, on which there may be reasonable disagreement.

36     In this case, S had been recently prescribed cetirizine about 1 month prior to the instance in issue where he was given cetirizine. In other words, a registered medical practitioner has already come to the view that S may consume cetirizine. A claims that the prescribing doctor is a general practitioner who is unaware of S’s history of epilepsy. However, there is little reliable basis for A’s contention, since A was not present at the consultation and is unable to testify as to the doctor’s history-taking and assessment. There is, in the first place, no reliable medical evidence that cetirizine cannot be prescribed for patients susceptible to epilepsy.

37     The documentary evidence shows an exchange between R and her helper indicating that the helper reporting that S had a runny nose and was sneezing, and had a blocked nose, and that R instructed the helper to feed cetirizine only if the sneezing did not clear after 5–10 minutes. Ultimately, it was also not alleged that S suffered any seizures as a result of cetirizine being administered.

38     A’s contention that R should not be fed cetirizine therefore is really a disagreement with R on how S’s situation should be managed. This is, in my view, clearly not FV.

Feeding S melatonin

39     R tendered a prescription for melatonin dated 25 Apr 2022 from KKH, which was less than 1 year before the alleged administration of melatonin. It indicated that it was to be taken pro re nata for sleep disturbance.

40     A argues that it would be harmful to S to feed him melatonin, based on a memo from Dr Phuah Huan Kee dated 14 August 2024, which opined that in S’s case melatonin may cause exacerbation of seizures. A says that R would have known about this because Dr Phuah had verbally cautioned both A and R in 2016 against giving melatonin to S, after having done an EEG in February 2016 which showed a peak. A also says that R had promised just shortly before giving melatonin that she would no longer give melatonin to S. Against this, R pointed out that Dr Phuah had himself administered melatonin to S. A also says that R deliberately withheld these test results from KKH to procure the melatonin prescription. R, however, said that she did not recall that melatonin was not to be administered.

41     In my view, the fact that Dr Phuah had himself administered melatonin to S counts for little. It is common ground that Dr Phuah administered melatonin only once, during the EEG. The point is that it was done under supervision, and that it led to the test results which led Dr Phuah to caution against the use of melatonin. Nonetheless, it is very tenuous to say that R has therefore committed FV. I observe that:

(a)     Dr Phuah was not here to give evidence. There was nothing in his report that stated that he had advised in 2016 not to feed S melatonin, even though one would assume that he keeps his medical records or notes. In other words, it is possible that Dr Phuah never cautioned against melatonin, or that the EEG findings may no longer be valid after a long passage of time. Although R did not give the EEG findings to the KKH doctors, I do not consider this to be a problem because:

(i)       There is insufficient evidence to satisfy me on a balance of probabilities that R deliberately withheld the EEG with a view to procuring a prescription for melatonin. Much less can it be said that R procured the prescription for melatonin by fraud.

(ii)       The doctors in KKH are also qualified to practice medicine, and they could have ordered the EEG if they considered it necessary.

(b)     If R wanted to feed melatonin, it seems to me that she would have done so on more occasions. Especially if A’s case was that R is prone to feeding medicine without an indication for it, it seems unlikely that R would wait until a seeming reason presented itself to feed R melatonin.

42     Likewise, it was also not alleged that S suffered any seizures as a result of melatonin being administered. In the circumstances, I take the view that it is clearly not FV to have administered melatonin to S.

Conclusion

43     In the context of managing a child who tends to exhibit SIB, or who has medical susceptibilities, parenting disagreements are only to be expected. However, a court, least of all one seised of the duty to determine whether FV has been committed, is patently the wrong forum to argue over whether family or parenting decisions have been optimised to manage the SIB, or to lay blame for sub-optimal decisions. That is a matter for A and R to sort out between themselves. In the final analysis, this summons really is, and really ought to be, about whether A has established on a balance of probabilities that R has committed FV and, thereafter, whether it is necessary to issue a PPO to protect the putative victim. And, in my judgment, the answer is a clear “no”.

44     In the circumstances, the summons is dismissed.

45     I order that A pay R costs of the proceedings fixed at $6,000 inclusive of disbursements, in view of the length of the trial, the nature of the allegations, R’s need to react to significant volumes of new material introduced by A on the first day of the trial, and the fact that time was wasted by A calling witnesses who added virtually nothing to the evidence because they lacked personal knowledge on most matters in issue.

XTM v XTN

XTM v XTN
[2025] SGFC 114

Case Number:Divorce No 1150 of 2024
Decision Date:19 December 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Shobha Nair
Counsel Name(s): Plaintiff in person; Stephanie Looi Min Yi (Constellation Law Chambers LLC) for the Defendant
Parties: XTM — XTN

Family Law – Ancillary Matters – Division of Matrimonial Assets – Maintenance for ex-spouse/children

19 December 2025

District Judge Shobha Nair:

Introduction

1       The plaintiff (wife) and the defendant (husband) were married in Argentina in October of 2009 and have 2 sons. Interim Judgment (IJ) dissolving the marriage was entered on 3 April 2024, making this a marriage of a little over 14 years in length. Parties had entered into an agreement on the custody, care and control as well as access to the children. Both sought to vary the consent order (via summons 1139 and 1447/2025). I dismissed the variation applications and issued the following orders on the ancillary matters.

(a)     The matrimonial assets of a net value of S$1,060,013.34 is to be divided 60:40 in favour of the plaintiff/wife. The defendant/husband is to effect payment of the sum the plaintiff/wife is entitled to within 6 months of the order.

(b)     The defendant is to pay maintenance of S$8 000 per month (S$4 000 for each child) with effect from 30 September 2025 and on the last day of each subsequent month.

(c)     The defendant shall be responsible for the children’s school fees which shall be paid directly by the defendant to the school.

(d)     The defendant shall be responsible for any hospitalisation costs for the children that is not covered by insurance.

(e)     The defendant shall pay to the plaintiff, maintenance of S$1 000 per month for a period of two (2) years from the date of this order or until the plaintiff is in full-time employment, whichever is earlier.

2       The husband appeals against the orders above. No appeal has been lodged with respect to the orders made on summons 1139 and 1447/2025.

Background

3       The wife is 50 years old. She is an Italian citizen who was until January 2025, an Executive Director, Global Head (Skills Based Organisation) at a bank in Singapore. She was unfortunately retrenched and was unemployed at the time of the hearing. She declared her last drawn gross monthly income to be S$26 000.[note: 1] The husband is 45 years of age and is an Australian citizen. He works as an Operations Program Manager at the Singapore office of a multinational technology company (Company X). He earns a gross monthly income of S$19 474.67.[note: 2]

4       After their marriage, both parties were working in Australia. The wife worked at a business management consultancy and the husband, at a utilities asset company. The husband was earning more than the wife at the time. Their first son was born in 2010, making him 15 years of age at the time of the hearing. The wife’s mother assisted in his care for a few months before the child was cared for at a childcare facility. In August 2011, the husband secured a job at Company X. While the work brought in a healthy income, it took him away from home for almost half of every month.[note: 3] The wife left her job at the business management consultancy in December 2012 and started her own business. The parties soon started to plan their move to Singapore. They believed that the move would afford them a better balance between their commitments at work and home. The husband managed to secure a transfer to Singapore and the family arrived in January 2015. At the time, she was expecting their second child. As the wife had considerable difficulty with previous pregnancies and had suffered miscarriages, it was thought prudent that she did not work during the pregnancy. After the child was born in August 2015, she secured work with a local bank, as Vice-President of Human Resources (HR) and then as Senior Vice-President of People Transformation until September 2021. The couple was assisted by a domestic helper from the time the second child was born. In September 2021, she assumed a new role as Executive Director at another bank. This job provided a significant increase in salary. Unfortunately, her services were terminated from January 2025.

5       While parties started to face challenges to their marriage from 2018, it was from about 2021 that significant cracks in the relationship began to surface. While the husband was in Australia visiting his family in 2023, the wife asked that he leave their rented premises on his return. He left in May 2023. He continued to contribute to the family expenses until December 2023 by depositing a monthly sum of S$12 500 into the parties’ joint account with DBS. He claims to have stopped providing further as the wife was utilising it to pay towards expenses they had not agreed on, including her credit card bills. Regardless, he continued to pay for the children’s school fees and expenses when they were with him. Finding it difficult to sustain expenses without the husband’s contribution, the wife took out an interim application for maintenance. This was heard and dismissed on 2 June 2025.[note: 4] As the rental of the premises the wife and children were staying at was S$13 000 per month and unsustainable, she had at the time of the hearing before me moved to cheaper accommodation.

6       The wife was acting in person but had sought the attendance of a solicitor to assist her during the proceedings. This was permitted with strict parameters drawn on the role of the solicitor during the proceedings. The husband had legal representation.

Division of Matrimonial Assets

7       Section 112 (1) of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev. Ed.) (Charter) provides that a court has the power subsequent to the grant of a judgment of divorce to order the division between parties of any matrimonial asset in such proportions as the court thinks just and equitable. Section 112 (2) provides a list of non-exhaustive factors to assist a court in determining what would be just and equitable.

8       Section 112 (10) provides the definition of a matrimonial asset. In USB v USA and another appeal[note: 5] the court expressed that “…..when a marriage is dissolved, in general all the parties’ assets will be treated as matrimonial assets unless a party is able to prove that any particular asset was either not acquired during the marriage or was acquired through a gift or inheritance and is therefore not a matrimonial asset. The party who asserts that an asset is not a matrimonial asset or that only a part of its value should be included in the pool bears the burden of proving this on the balance of probabilities…”[note: 6]

Sums withdrawn from the DBS joint account

9       It is trite law that substantial sums expended when divorce is imminent must be returned to the pool.[note: 7] The plaintiff called for the court to make a finding that S$80 828.34 was improperly withdrawn by her husband from their joint DBS account without her knowledge and that this sum be returned by the husband.[note: 8] The husband made a similar allegation against his wife and said that he stopped contributing a monthly sum of S$12 500 to prevent her from using the monies on expenses they did not agree on.[note: 9] I did not place the sum indicated by the wife to have been spent by the husband (nor suggested by the husband to be unreasonable expenses of the wife) back into the pool for division. From the evidence, both parties contributed to this account with the understanding that the monies were to be utilised for various expenses of the family. Even though they earned healthy incomes, their expenses were disproportionately high and the substantial spending from this account was by both parties and largely to meet those expenses which snowballed once parties started to live separately and divorce proceedings commenced. The wife alleged that the husband did not explain every withdrawal and appeared to be “cherry-picking”[note: 10] items he could explain. I did not agree. It is impossible for every expense to be accounted for in a marriage. In this case, a lot of what appears to be large payments relate to credit card bills which in turn relate to unmanaged family expenses and expensive school fees. The husband was able to show that he met many of the family expenses from the joint account and there was no credible suggestion that he was removing or utilising it to avoid a fair division.

Joint accounts held with children not drawn into the pool

10     The husband was of the view that the accounts held in the joint names of the children and the wife formed part of the wife’s assets.[note: 11] I did not place it into the pool of assets to be divided, not on account of it being a modest collective sum but largely because the intention behind the setting up of these accounts was to provide the children with a resource to meet expenses, if needed. In any event, the husband eventually took the position that these need not be brought into the pool for division.[note: 12]

Date of determination of asset value

11     The parties presented 2 different computations of the value of the matrimonial assets, arising significantly from the difference in the date each party proposed as the relevant date for the determination of asset value. In ARY v ARX[note: 13] the court articulated that the default position to determine the pool of matrimonial assets is the date the interim judgment was issued, in this case, 3 April 2024. The court opined that “unless the particular circumstances of justice of the case warrant it, the starting point or default position should be the date that interim judgment is granted”.[note: 14] In the case before me, the husband left the home in May 2023 but had a continuous relationship with the family after this and before the divorce. He contributed financially into the joint account for the children’s expenses after moving out and once that ceased, their school fees and other expenses. Parties even continued to travel as a family. It would be prudent to apply the date of IJ as the effective date of determination of the matrimonial assets. I accepted to a large extent the computation of the husband as provided at Annex C of his final submissions.

The net value of the matrimonial assets

12     In this case, there was no matrimonial home which was purchased by the parties as they had lived together in rented premises throughout their marriage, and separately in rented premises since May 2023. There was no dispute as to the relevance of any pre-marital asset or inheritance which the husband had received. Having determined the issues relating to the disputed assets and the date at which the assets ought to be computed, the value of assets and liabilities closest to the date of IJ is provided at Table 1. While I agree that the values of unvested shares provided by the husband is subject to variables such as the performance of the company and that it may therefore only represent ballpark values on vesting, any loss of value would be borne by both, as would any gain.

13     As this was a marriage of 14 years during which time the parties were in full time employment save for brief periods, the structured approach advanced by the Court in ANJ v ANK[note: 19] was applied. First, a ratio that represents each party’s direct contributions relative to the other party was ascribed, having regard to the amount of financial contribution each party had made towards the acquisition and improvement of the matrimonial assets. Then, their indirect contributions relative to each other was ascribed a ratio before arriving at an average ratio.[note: 20]

14     Having found that the direct contributions of the parties were approximately in the proportion 38% (wife): 62% (husband),[note: 21] I turned to their indirect contributions. The husband was of the view that the indirect contributions of the parties were equal. I was of the view that a fairer division ought to be 65:35 in favour of the wife.

15     Even as the parties managed their work and household chores without helpers till the birth of their second child in 2015, the wife appears in my view to be the one who was more consistent in providing for the family and whose contribution was of a nature that connoted a larger responsibility when it came to the care of the children. They were both good providers of financial support. The wife’s income relative to the husband’s was larger only from 2021 but it allowed for greater contribution to the family expenses from that time. Her lower pay before 2021 (relative to her husband’s) would also need to be understood in the context of the manner in which the husband dealt with his salary. Deductions from his salary was made to pay for the OCBC SRS account as well as the Superannuation Fund in Australia.[note: 22] This lowered his available salary for family expenses. Notwithstanding, I am of the view that this was less of a concern given that it was accounted for in the pool of assets. The deductions to his salary for the purchase of shares which amounted to almost S$2 000 a month however was of greater relevance as it reduced available income to meet family expenses. The wife’s salary on the other hand was fully applied to meet the family expenses.

16     Apart from the time the wife was on maternity leave for 4 months and what appears to be a 2-month paternity leave the husband was on after the birth of their first son in 2010, the husband was away substantially every month for work related matters when he was working for Company X in Australia. This was between 2011 and the end of 2014. During these years, the care of the first son would have fallen on the wife, assisted for a brief time by her mother. When the couple arrived in Singapore in 2015 the wife did not work during her pregnancy. During this time, the husband was the sole provider and she would have been with her older child, assisted this time by a domestic helper. However, in 2020 the husband stopped work for a period of about a year which placed the economic responsibility on the wife. The husband claimed that he wanted to homeschool the children during the Covid-19 pandemic which they feared would impact the health of their second son in particular. The wife disagreed with the husband’s reason for ceasing employment and attributed it to the stress that he felt during that time. Regardless of the reason, the family lost income during this period in addition to share entitlements/benefits. The relationship came under intense pressure from 2021 and the husband chose to travel to Australia to be with his brothers. In May 2023 he was asked to leave the home making his contributions to daily care of the children rather more limited for the year prior to April 2024. In essence, approximately 4 of their 14-year marriage saw the husband either travelling for significant periods each month for work or living separately from the children (on account of being told to do so), thus limiting his caregiving. I could not ignore the fact that the wife must have shouldered the responsibility more, at least for those 4 years. As for the remaining years, clearly it can be said, as it can for almost every marriage, that contributions were made by both parents to the care of their children. The husband spoke of having shared equally in the discharge of responsibilities towards the children. The wife did not agree and suggested that he was in fact an absent father. The husband understandably rejected such a position and shared examples of his contribution. He spoke of feeding and putting his first son to sleep after night feeds, taking the children on “scooter rides”, bringing them to parties and to the doctor when his wife could not. These amongst others, were contributions that were taken into consideration. From the affidavits however, it appears that the wife was the one who largely liaised with school, tutors and doctors. The husband stepped in, without any hesitation, but usually when she could not. The husband also appears to prefer the children deciding what was good for them. An example would be drum lessons which the second son had taken. This was to assist in the management of ADHD. It was stopped when the son indicated a lack of interest.[note: 23] Similarly when the child indicated that he was bored with therapy sessions with a psychologist, the husband was of the view that the child need not attend.[note: 24] The wife enrolled the child for a sleep study to better address his challenges which the husband did not agree with. Additionally, and more recently, he appears to be more comfortable contributing to the needs of the children if such needs or events occurred during his time with the children. When an appointment the wife made with a Ear, Nose and Throat (ENT) specialist for the second child did not fall on his time with the children, he was of the view that the wife should then take him.[note: 25] While the husband need not take the child each time he is asked to, the position he takes on when he has an obligation to do so, i.e., when he has the child with him, paints a larger picture of compartmentalising duties and how the onus to meet the needs of the children continuously resides with the mother. Insofar as his explanation on why he agreed to cancelling classes the children were not interested in, this could be viewed simply as differing parenting styles. The wife’s view that the children should take on or commit to programmes that would help them manage their ADHD in particular and her commitment to following through with them shows a parent that was willing to do more to address these issues. It would have been easier to allow the children to drop activities they found uninteresting. It may not however be in their best interest.

17     The husband spoke rather more broadly on the money he had provided to meet the children’s expenses.[note: 26] While this is certainly important, both seem to have contributed well with the last 4 years seeing a larger contribution by the wife. The larger disparity between the parties appear to be in their respective contributions to the care and well-being of the children. I was of the view that the wife catered towards this more substantially and greater weight for her indirect contributions was accordingly given. Where both parents work, the amount of time available for their children may not differ materially but the nature of care may well be divergent. Other forms of indirect contribution such as that relating to the wife having assisted the husband to secure work at Company X or planning the logistics of the family’s move to Singapore, were not taken into account in the decision to award her a higher percentage for her indirect contributions. There was little by way of credible evidence to suggest that either did more than the other in these areas.

Adjustments to the average ratio

18     Guided by the court in ANJ, I looked at 3 broad categories relating to the length of marriage, the size of the assets and its constituents and the nature of the indirect contributions of the parties[note: 27] in addition to several other relevant factors provided under s 112(2) of the Charter in making adjustments to the average ratio and arriving at an appropriate division.

19     Apart from the relevant factors stated in preceding paragraphs, I considered the needs of the children further.

20     The wife suspected that both boys may have Attention Deficit Hyperactive Disorder (ADHD). Assessments indicate that they have the disorder. The second son’s condition appears to be one which requires more attention. The road ahead for the wife who will be caring for their day-to-day needs will require a greater and more involved presence and closer care and engagement with the school and support providers. Additionally, the children were until the time they had to move into their current rented premises, used to a lifestyle more luxurious on account of the fact that both parents were earning healthy incomes. With the loss of employment on the wife’s part, more than half of the family income is no longer available, bringing with it substantial uncertainty. It is very likely as the wife herself had acknowledged, that their continued stay in Singapore is contingent on her finding suitable work. The wife is 50 years of age and regardless of her skills, her ability to obtain employment at the salary level the family was used to, is unlikely. Providing a buffer to the wife who has the care and control of the children was felt to be needed hence an adjustment was made. Given the relatively modest net value of assets, a 3.5% adjustment was made (which translates to a real value of about $37 000).

The husband’s remuneration package – a lack of full and frank disclosure

21     The wife asserted that “No one at [Company X] works for the cash they are paid.”[note: 28]As part of his company’s compensation structure, employees at Company X, earn shares as restricted stock units (RSU). 25% of the shares could be encashed after 1 year of being granted and 75% was similarly cashable every quarter or bi-annually over 4 years after it is granted. Shares were also granted through an employee salary sacrifice scheme (ESPP) and other equity-based instruments. It was the wife’s position that the husband dissipated and concealed his share portfolio and associated cash proceeds from the sale of shares.

22     While initially the husband appeared to be saying that rewards for personal work was not a matrimonial asset, submissions by his counsel accepted that vested shares and shares granted but unvested as at the time of the IJ should be retained in the matrimonial pool of assets to be divided. With regards to the vested shares, he provided statements from an E-trade Morgan Stanley Account, the account through which shares are traded, to show its value as at April 2024[note: 29] and highlighted also that he had given a sum of $43 000 to his wife, which he said represented half of the amount he received from the sale of vested shares.[note: 30] Dissatisfied, the wife applied for discovery. One of the orders related to the need to produce documents to state the number of shares he owns whether provided by his company or purchased between April 2022 and March 2023. The judge who heard the application also noted that apart from the shares granted as part of the remuneration package, there was a need to disclose information on the additional shares purchased through the salary sacrifice scheme for the same period. In his affidavit attempting to comply with the orders, the husband produced instead the E-Trade Morgan Stanley accounts from 2023.[note: 31] He said[note: 32] “Although the plaintiff requested for information/documents from April 2022, the disclosure sought for by the plaintiff is too extensive and onerous upon me. Further, I fail to see how the old statements would be relevant. I have therefore disclosed the information only from April 2023 onwards (i.e. the period when I moved out) and verily believe such extent disclosure (sic) is sufficient for the court to adequately determine my financial resources”. This was a position unilaterally taken despite the court order. This threw up many questions with respect to the period before he left the matrimonial home and how those shares were dealt with, including the nature of expenditure from the shares if sold. With respect to the ESPP, a sum of $1 947 is deducted from his salary every month for its purchase. Information was not forthcoming on the number of shares he had between April 2022 and March 2023, disabling any submission on the prudence of how the sale proceeds, if any, was applied. Even for the period March 2023 to April 2024, he failed to identify the ESPP in the statements exhibited in his compliance affidavit. In his 2nd affidavit for the ancillary matters,[note: 33] he claimed that the E-Trade Morgan Stanley Statements provides details of it while saying at the same time that he sold the shares as soon as he purchased them.[note: 34] He made no attempt to show the number of shares he held under the ESPP and how the figures aligned with his position that he utilised the proceeds for credit card loans immediately upon sale. Parties indeed “…bear a duty to approach the division process with candour, diligence and a genuine commitment to resolution”.[note: 35] An inference was made that the husband failed to fully account for the number of shares he had, in particular that which he purchased through deductions from his salary.

23     Adverse inferences should only be drawn if “there is a substratum of evidence that establishes a prima facie case against the person against whom the inference is to be drawn and that person had some particular access to the information he is said to be hiding”.[note: 36] There are 2 approaches that will allow an adverse inference arising out of non-disclosure to be effected. One would be for a court to make a finding on the estimated value of undisclosed assets and include that value in the matrimonial pool of assets to be divided. This however would be effective typically, if there is available evidence. It can however be utilised even in the absence of it as seen in BPC. The other approach would be for the court to order a higher proportion of the assets to the other party.[note: 37] The lack of candour with respect to the true extent of his shares between April 2022 and April 2024 and if they were sold, where that value was deposited and how it was applied required in my view an uplift of 5% to be ascribed to the wife’s share.

24     Looking at the facts in totality and bearing in mind the continued relevance of the broad-brush approach, the following were the ratios for direct and indirect contributions, adjustments made to the average ratio and the 5% uplift for failure on the part of the husband to disclose his share portfolio fully in compliance with orders made pursuant to the discovery application.

Maintenance for the wife and children

25     At the time of the hearing, the wife and children had moved from their previous rented premises, thus necessitating an update of the expenses of the family. The wife provided by way of further submissions a new table of expenses which is reproduced below. Where figures reflected the cost per school term or annually, the monthly cost is reflected by dividing the given figure by the number of months. For ease of reference, the wife’s position on some aspects of the expenses are also reflected in the table.

26     The appropriate maintenance to be ordered for children is one that reflects a balance between the means of the party paying and the needs of those receiving. S 68 of the Charter makes it clear that the duty to maintain children is placed on both parents. S 127 of the Charter provides for an order of maintenance to be made where a couple divorces or is in the process of doing so. The provisions within Parts 8 and 9 of the Charter apply. Insofar as the maintenance of former wives are concerned, the power to make an order is found in s 113 of the Charter. S 114 goes on to spell out various factors that may be taken into consideration in the determination of what may be reasonable. An important factor would be the income, earning capacity, property and other financial resources which each of the parties to the marriage has or is likely to have in the foreseable future, the ages of parties, the standard of living enjoyed by the family prior to the breakdown of the marriage and the responsiblilies and needs each party has or is likely to have in the forseable future.[note: 38]

27     Given that the wife was no longer drawing an income from January 2025, the husband’s responsibilities became significantly larger. I was mindful that the lack of contribution by the wife at this time should not translate to the husband then providing for the same lifestyle the children were accustomed to as this would cripple him financially. I understand that with divorce and the creation of a new norm including setting up 2 households, has signficant impact on the financial situation of families. Clearly adjustments would have to be made. However, it did mean that for this time and until such time the wife finds suitable employment or if the children are compelled to relocate given that the wife’s residency in Singapore is linked to her employment here, the husband had to stretch his dollar to meet the needs of the family. What then are his means and expenses? He produced a table as follows:[note: 39]

28     The husband’s income as declared in his affidavit[note: 40] is $19 474.67. He declared his net monthly income to be between $17 000 to $18 000 as almost S$2 000 would be deducted for the ESPP scheme[note: 41] and contributions to his SRS. From a quick glance of the expenses of both parties, it is clear that even with the wife working, they were not able to meet expenses. With the wife not working, they need to relook their living expenses and school expenses of the children which are taking up the bulk of the available income. In VBR v VBS[note: 42] the court was of the view that a reasonable parent who is paying maintenance should live within his means and not take on unnecessary financial obligations which would reduce his ability to provide. The husband says that he had taken on accomodation at a relatively high rent of $6 000 per month to allow the children more space during access. While his wife denies having suggested this need, this is an expense that could be reduced if it is causing an inability to meet other expenses including maintenance. To be clear, I did not think that he was intentionally taking on such an expense to reduce his obligations. Insofar as school expenses are concerned which is taking up a substantial amount, it was a joint decision that the children be placed in an international school in Singapore. It would not be possible to place them in local schools at this time, even if the option were available. The reality is that they need to be kept in school until such time the wife obtains employment which will then allow her to resume her responsibility to maintain the children with their father. In XPG v XPH[note: 43] the court similarly found it to be in the best interests of the child to continue his education at an international school, having already completed 1.5 years there. The court opined that any disruption to the current school arrangement may adversely affect the child’s academic progress and emotional well-being. In the case before me, the order enabling the husband to deal directly with the school was to allow for some flexibitlity in the short-term, (i.e., pending greater certainty in the wife’s professional life), in drawing up a payment plan. This is of course subject to the school’s agreement. The payment of school fees is not realistically to come from his net salary every month and would need to be drawn from his assets, bonuses and share returns. Documents showing his past annual income is able to meet this if he manages it carefully. Given that the elder child will be sitting for the international GCSE soon, it would be vital that this period of time pass without interruption. Additionally, the school the children are at provide support for students with ADHD.[note: 44] Conversations as to the long term plans for schooling however would inevitably need to take place.

29     The order of monthly maintenance of $4 000 per child ($8 000 per month in total) was ordered on a computation of reasonable expenses as follows:

30     Even if only the most basic of expenses are taken into account, the figure stands at $8 600. I did not take into account many other items which the children were used to having. I also did not include expenditure that a parent with care and control would in any case incur even if she did not have care and control.[note: 45]The maintenance amount would also need to be utilised to pay for services which the husband is currently paying for. Insofar as medical and dental expenses are concerned, insurance coverage can be activated when needed. For all medical expenses which are not so covered, the maintenance amount would need to be used to meet those. Therefore if the children are to consult a general practitioner and the cost is not covered by insurance, this is to be paid from the maintenance amount. The only exception when the maintenance amount need not be used for medical expenses (which are not covered by insurance) is in the event of hospitalisation as the charges are likely to be high.

31     I allowed a sum of $1 000 per month as maintenance for the ex-wife for a period of 2 years or until she secures employment, whichever is earlier, so as to provide some assistance with rent and food at this time. I am in agreement with the husband that she had always been financially independent and that they had jointly contributed resources for the maintenance of the family. She did not in the past depend on the provision of spousal maintenance which would typically be of some relevance in deciding if she should be entitled to any, post-divorce. I was of the view however that some support for a limited period against the backdrop of a rather more affluent lifestyle in the past, would be fair.

Conclusion

32     With the unfortunate termination of the wife’s employment, a significant source of family income was no longer available, making it important to determine the division of matrimonial assets with the larger interests of the children in mind. This is so especially because parties do not own property and the net value of assets is relatively modest. The maintenance obligation on the husband is not a light one but it is likely to be temporary. The maintenance orders are, in my view, necessary given the need to provide stability to the children both in terms of their living arrangements and their education. The husband would need, as would the wife and children, make rather dramatic changes to lifestyle to meet their long term needs.
